Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop algorithmically scalable high-order numerical techniques. The essential components consist of numerically-constructed one-dimensional basis functions, which correspond to a set of optimal bases in the function space in some sense. Expansion bases for higher dimensions are then developed from such functions. Methods employing these new bases exhibit superior properties in terms of numerical efficiency and algorithmic scalability.

The investigator develops techniques that make computer simulations of physical processes both very accurate and very fast. These computer simulations permeate essentially every aspect of modern life. They are indispensable and critical to, for example, the design of airplanes and spacecrafts, discovery and design of new materials, understanding and prediction of severe weather conditions such as tornadoes and hurricanes, understanding and prevention of oil spills. The significance of the project lies in that the techniques developed herein can significantly reduce the time to acquire the solutions in simulations, and simultaneously substantially increase the simulation accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of this project we have developed computational tools, methods and algorithms that substantially advance the computational science, in particular, computational fluid dynamics. Some of these methods provide effective techniques to overcome certain long-standing issues in computer simulations for a class of flow problems, and other methods have enabled the computer simulations for certain classes of fluid-flow problems that were not possible before.

Specifically, the scientific advances are in terms of the following three aspects. First, we have developed a set of methods (energy-stable open boundary conditions and algorithms) that effectively eliminate the backflow instability issue for single-phase flows with open/outflow boundaries. Backflow instability is an issue that has hampered computer simulations of inflow/outflow type problems for a long time. Second, we have developed a set of effective methods for efficiently simulating two-phase flows involving outflows and open boundaries. Two-phase outflows are a class of problems that were not amenable to computer simulations before. Our methods have provided the fundamental techniques for effective and efficient computations for this class of problems. Third, we have developed mathematical models, numerical methods, and computation algorithms for efficient simulations of multiphase flows consisting of an arbitrary number of fluid components. The class of multiphase problems have enormous application potentials in many engineering areas. Our models and formulations provide a physically-consistent theoretical framework and foundation for computing these problems.

In addition to the scientific advancements, this project has also provided opportunities for the training and growth of next-generation computational scientists and mathematicians. Several graduate students and undergraduate students have been trained and benefitted from the project. The project has also imprinted on the applied math curriculum. A new course on the spectral element technique has been developed at Purdue University.
